frame.name: Negation
frame.definition:
<def-root>This frame models the semantic contribution of negation, in which the profiled content of the <fen>Negated_proposition</fen> is asserted to contrast incompatibly with a corresponding <fen>Factual_situation</fen>, which is normally implicit. The <fen>Negated_proposition</fen> and the <fen>Factual_situation</fen> share non-focal content, on the basis of which they correspond, and contrast in a subset of their content, the focal content, established with reference to a set of focus constructions not described here. (The focus of negation is often conveyed intonationally in spoken English; in text, however, negative focus must be derived inferentially from contextual reference. A subset of focus constructions will be annotated in the constructicon.) <ex></ex> While the semantics of negation are quite different from the semantics belonging to most frames, at a minimum, our modeling of the concept using frame semantic tools can be viewed as a practical attempt to label a problem and annotate examples that may inform further research. <ex></ex> Negation can be evoked verbally (analytic or synthetic) or nominally. Negators include "not", "no", "never", and negational affixes, such as those used on inflected verbs in synthetic verbal negation (wasn't, isn't, haven't).
<ex><fex name="Negated_proposition">It 's</fex> <t>not</t> <fex name="Negated_proposition">far from here</fex> . <fex name="Factual_situation">INI</fex></ex> <ex><fex name="Negated_proposition">She 's</fex> <t>not</t> <fex name="Negated_proposition">smart</fex> , <fex name="Factual_situation">she 's sly</fex> .</ex>
</def-root>

FE.name: Negated_proposition
FE.definition:
<def-root>The situation which is presented as false overall. The particular focus of negation which contrasts with the <fen>Factual_situation</fen> is not separately marked.
<ex><fex name="Negated_proposition">She did</fex><t>n't</t> <fex name="Negated_proposition">know</fex>, rather she suspected.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Negated_proposition">She had</fex> <t>not</t> <fex name="Negated_proposition">one</fex>, but two <fex name="Negated_proposition">books on transcendentalism .</fex></ex>
<ex><fex name="Negated_proposition">I did</fex> <t>n't</t> <fex name="Negated_proposition">say anything</fex> , but rather paced all the more nervously .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Factual_situation
FE.definition:
<def-root>The situation or part of situation that actually pertains, in contradistinction to the profiled situation in the <fen>Negated_proposition</fen> that is asserted not to pertain. In spoken language and casual written language, but not in normatively edited written texts, the <fen>Factual_situation</fen> may be expressed as an unmarked clause immediately preceding or following the <fen>Negated_proposition</fen>.
<ex>She did <t>n't</t> know, <fex name="Factual_situation">rather she suspected</fex> .</ex> <ex>She had <t>not</t> one, <fex name="Factual_situation">but two</fex> books on transcendentalism .</ex> <ex>I did <t>n't</t> say anything , <fex name="Factual_situation">but rather paced all the more nervously</fex> .</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: not.adv
lexUnit.definition: FN: a simple negator that most often follows auxiliary verbs

lexUnit.name: never.adv
lexUnit.definition: FN: a negator that can precede or follow aux verbs, and that can precede regular verbs.

lexUnit.name: no.art
lexUnit.definition: FN: a negating article that precedes a noun phrase

lexUnit.name: no longer.adv
lexUnit.definition: FN: a negation phrase that precedes or follows an auxiliary or regular verb

lexUnit.name: far.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: absolutely not; often used in contexts where not only is the negated proposition false, but there are salient implications that are also false.
